docs.title: Connections
docs.text:
Welcome to Connections, an interactive resource for exploring biblical people, places, tribes, and themes. This project visualizes relationships across the Bible and related sources, providing a rich reference for pastors, scholars, and curious readers alike.

Connections was created by a software engineer with a passion for biblical studies. It applies network and graph theory to connect ideas, themes, people, and places, offering both intuitive exploration and scholarly depth.

docs.title: What Connections Does
docs.text:
• Maps biblical relationships: who is connected to whom, familial lineages, tribal affiliations, and thematic links.
  • Each page includes references, notes, and visualizations showing its connections to other pages.
  • Includes Old Testament, New Testament, and extra-biblical references for every page.
  • Highlights strong and weak connections to help identify important links and scholarly debates.
  • Supports modular expansion: new pages, connections, or categories can be added via structured data (YAML) files.

docs.title: Browsing
docs.text:
• Search for primary agents like People, Places, Tribes, and Themes using the search bar or nav panel.
  • Click on a page to view detailed information, references, notes, and visualizations of its connections.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Biblical references link to authoritative sources (BibleHub).
  • Academic and extra-biblical references are listed for further study.

docs.title: Visualizations
docs.text:
• Each page may include charts showing connections (family, groups, themes).
  • Charts are generated from the underlying data, so new pages automatically appear.

docs.title: About Us
docs.text:
Welcome! I'm the creator and maintainer of White Tree Bible—a project built (so far) from scratch by a single software engineering manager (and dad of four) living in Boise, Idaho.

I grew up as an aviation missionary kid in Indonesia, attended school in Malaysia, and moved to the U.S. for college. My lifelong love for the Bible, combined with inspiration from the Bible Project (Tim Mackie), led me to pursue a master's degree in Biblical Exposition (hopefully graduating in Fall 2025).

This site is a labor of love, built on nights and weekends, aiming to help others explore the rich connections between people, places, and themes in the Bible. I hope it inspires curiosity, deeper study, and a sense of wonder at the biblical story. May your life advance in every way as you delight in the instruction of Yahweh day and night!

Thank you for visiting and being part of this journey!

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing! Connections is a collaborative project to map biblical figures, tribes, places, and themes. Contributions follow a clear workflow to ensure data integrity.

docs.title: Financial Contributors
docs.text: Someday, I would love to spend more than a few hours here or there on nights and weekends contributing to this project, but my day-job is still a big part of my life. Once I setup a way to donate, I'll have a way to track if this is a project that can be supported by my full-time work. I'll keep you posted.

docs.title: Academic Contributors
docs.text: As a Bible enthusiast, I hope that others who love to study the Bible want to contribute to this (rather large) potential body of work! I welcome emails and

docs.title: Software Dev Contributors
docs.text:
We welcome contributions! To add new pages or update connections:

  1. Create or modify YAML files in the data/ folder.
  2. Run the build script to generate updated Markdown pages.
  3. Submit a pull request to the repository for review.

For more details, see out contribution guidelines

  1. Clone or fork the repo
git clone https://github.com/whitetreebible/connections.git
cd connections
  1. Install dependencies If you don't have it, install UV first
source .venv/bin/activate
  1. Serve the web
tom yaml
tom serve
  1. Submit a Pull Request:
  2. Make sure all YAML is validated (see scripts/validate_yaml.py).1

  3. PR should include new nodes or updates; generated Markdown will be reviewed automatically.

  4. Deploy the web

tom deploy
  • This will build the static site and push it to the gh-pages branch where Github Pages is serving.

docs.title: Workflow
docs.text:
graph LR;

Bible --> Yaml
Resources --> Yaml
Books --> Yaml

Yaml -->|Ingestion| SQLite
Yaml --> Generators
SQLite --> Generators

Generators --> Markdown

Markdown --> MkDocs

  1. Doesn't exist yet, but someday it will. ↩

docs.title: Project Status
docs.text: Hey, you found the project status page... you must be interested beyond the typical user--welcome!

docs.title: Phase 1: POC
docs.text:
• Completed 2025-09-04 (ish)
  • Demonstrate the graphs in a manual way that seemed promising!

docs.title: Phase 2: Core Build
docs.text:
• Completed 2025-09-13
  • refactor/rename/rebuild so it's scalable/testable/usable - done!
  • nice to haves:
  • transition away from makefile, I need a better script runner framework - done 2025-09-12
  • move static files to their own location so a clean build can be done more simply and comprehensively - done 2025-09-13
  • identify a good way to add incrementally instead of rebuilding everything. versions on nodes? - punt
  • create a way to heal/suggest missing reciprocal links - punt

docs.title: Phase 3: Import Ruth
docs.text:
• In progress
  • all of Ruth links--mostly by hand according to defined categories
  • While it is far slower to do by hand. I'm already coming away with fresh insights from the first chapter of Ruth. For example, I always thought Elimelech's kids married before he died and then they all died over time, but it looks like he died then Naomi arranged marriages for his sons to foreign women. Also, it looks like Ruth and Orpah may have been infertile--which would put Ruth into a whole pattern of miraculous conceptions. Maybe there's something to the by-hand method--however slow that maybe.
  • this does not include any academic resources, just Bible

docs.title: Phase 4: Torah
docs.text:
• add subscription/support ability (who knows, maybe this can become a career instead of a weekend project)
  • share with trusted academics/pastors/influencers
  • complete Ge-De

docs.title: Phase 5
docs.text: • See where it goes?

docs.title: Boaz (kinsman redeemer of Ruth, from Bethlehem)
docs.text: Boaz was a wealthy landowner in Bethlehem and a prominent figure in the Book of Ruth. He is the son of Salmon and Rahab, and becomes the husband of Ruth. Boaz is the great-grandfather of King David and is mentioned in the genealogy of person/jesus in Matthew 1:5-6.

docs.title: Associations
docs.text:
• Married to Ruth (Matthew 1:5, Ruth 4:13)
  • Parent of Obed (Ruth 4:17, Ruth 4:21)
  • Resident of Bethlehem (Ruth 2:1)
  • Child of Salmon (Matthew 1:5, Ruth 4:21)
  • Child of Rahab (Matthew 1:5)
  • Member of Judah (Ruth 2:1)
  • Visited Bethlehem (Ruth 2:4)
  • Gave-to Ruth (Ruth 2:14)
  • Associated with field (Ruth 2:3)
  • Example of hospitality (Ruth 2:14)
  • Role as redeemer (Ruth 2:20, Ruth 3:9)
  • Associated with drinking (Ruth 3:7, 1)
  • Associated with wing (Ruth 3:9, 2)
  • Associated with will_not_rest (Ruth 3:18)
  • Associated with city_gate (Ruth 4:1)

  1. "And Boaz drank and ate until his heart was good" is an idiom for getting drunk. Boaz celebrated with the reapers, had a lot to drink, and made good choices (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

  2. Boaz says in 2:1 "May Yahweh reward your work and may a full reward be given to you from Yahweh, the God of Israel, under whose wings you came to take refuge" and in 3:9, Ruth asks him to "Spread your wing over your servant because you are a redeemer." This is likely an allusion to Ruth taking refuge under the wings of God, and Boaz is being asked to symbolically do the same by spreading his "wing" (sometimes translated garment) over her. This is a culturally significant gesture indicating protection and care, akin to the way God protects His people (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

  1. The redeemer of whom Boaz had spoken is not named, but he is likely a close relative of Elimelech, possibly a brother or cousin. He has the first right of right/responsibility of redeem the land and marry Ruth according to the custom of levirate marriage (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

  2. The "unsandaled one" is a reference to Leviticus 25:9, "she shall pull off his sandal from his foot, and she shall spit in his face," which describes a shameful practice where the kinsman-redeemer is publicly humiliated, apparently it had been normalized by this time into an accepted cultural practice (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

docs.title: Rahab (prostitute from Jericho)
docs.text: Rahab was a tribe/canaan woman in place/jericho who hid the tribe/israel spies sent by person/joshua. Because of her actions, she and her family were spared during the conquest of the city.1 She is later mentioned in the genealogy of Jesus in Matthew 1:5 and praised for her faith in Hebrews 11:31. Scholars note that she should not be confused with the creature/rahab_monster mentioned in Psalm 89:10 and Job 26:12. Rahab's story bridges the Old and New Testaments. Some extra-biblical sources, like Josephus2, recount her story in a similar way to Joshua 2. Her inclusion among women in Jesus' genealogy is notable and discussed in multiple commentaries. Scholarly debate exists on the historical versus symbolic elements of her story.

docs.text:
• Resident of place/jericho (Joshua 2, 3)
  • Member of tribe/canaanite (Joshua 2)

  • Name matches creature/rahab (Job 26:12, Psalm 89:10)
  • Ancestor of person/jesus (Matthew 1:5, 4)
  • Example of theme/faith (Hebrews 11:31, James 2:25)
  • Assisted group/israelite_spies (Joshua 2)
  • Parent of Boaz (Matthew 1:5)
  • Married to Salmon (Matthew 1:5)

  1. This is a test footnote for demonstration purposes, it has a person/jesus link and a Joshua 2 link. ↩

  2. "Josephus recounts Rahab hiding the spies and her family's preservation during Jericho's conquest."" (Josephus, Flavius, Antiquities of the Jews, Book 5, Section 1.) ↩

  3. "To retain the traditional understanding of zonah as "prostitute," ..." (Victor P. Hamilton, Handbook on the Historical Books, Grand Rapids, MI: Baker Academic, 2001, 22.) ↩

  4. "Rahab's inclusion among women in Jesus' genealogy is significant and discussed in multiple commentaries." (Beale, G. K., Commentary on the New Testament Use of the Old Testament, pp. 208-212.) ↩

    person/ruth -->|example of| theme/humility

  1. 10 years of marriage without children may indicate infertility for both Orpah and Ruth (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

  2. "Opening the feet" is a euphemism for sexual relations. It is unclear what exactly Ruth did, but it was likely more than just uncovering his feet while he slept (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

  3. Boaz says in 2:1 "May Yahweh reward your work and may a full reward be given to you from Yahweh, the God of Israel, under whose wings you came to take refuge" and in 3:9, Ruth asks him to "Spread your wing over your servant because you are a redeemer." This is likely an allusion to Ruth taking refuge under the wings of God, and Boaz is being asked to symbolically do the same by spreading his "wing" (sometimes translated garment) over her. This is a culturally significant gesture indicating protection and care, akin to the way God protects His people (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

  4. "Yahweh enabled her to conceive" indicates that Ruth had difficulty conceiving and Yahweh overcame said difficulties (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

docs.title: Salmon (husband of Rahab)
docs.text: Salmon was a member of the tribe of tribe/judah and is noted in biblical genealogies as the husband of Rahab and the father of Boaz. He is mentioned in the genealogy of person/jesus in Matthew 1:4-5. Little else is known about Salmon, but his marriage to Rahab is significant in the biblical narrative, linking the story of the conquest of Jericho to the lineage of King David and Jesus.
